==German== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|de|gmh|donerstac}}, from {{inh|de|goh|donarestag}}, {{m|goh|thonarestag}} (11th c.), from late {{inh|de|gem-pro|*Þunras dagaz||day of Thor}}. Compare {{cog|nds|Dunnersdag}}, {{cog|nl|donderdag}}, {{cog|fy|tongersdei}}, {{cog|en|Thursday}}, {{cog|da|torsdag}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/ˈdɔnɐsˌtaːk/}} {{a|standard}} * {{audio|de|De-Donnerstag.ogg|Audio}} :* {{IPA|de|/ˈdɔnɐsˌtax/}} {{a|northern Germany and parts of central Germany; chiefly colloquial}} :* {{IPA|de|/ˈdɔnɐsˌtaːx/}} {{a|parts of central Germany; chiefly colloquial}} ===Noun=== {{de-noun|m|Donnerstages|gen2=Donnerstags|Donnerstage}} # [[Thursday]] ====Declension==== {{de-decl-noun-m|(e)s|e}} ====Synonyms==== * (''primarily Bavarian'') {{l|de|Pfinztag}} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|de|Gründonnerstag}} ===See also=== * {{list:days of the week/de}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:Duden}} [[Category:de:Days of the week]]
